event: You are lying in your crib when your primary caregiver approaches with a colorful, noisy rattle. You are starting to notice the world around you more clearly. How do you react to this new stimulus?

options.d: Cry from overstimulation

event: You are sitting up with support and your parents introduce your first solid food: a spoonful of mashed peas. You aren't sure about this new texture.

options.d: Close mouth tight

event: You are beginning to crawl and have discovered a low-reaching bookshelf. A heavy, colorful book is teetering on the edge.

options.d: Try to push it back in

event: It is your first birthday party. A group of relatives is singing loudly and crowding around you while a cake with a bright flame is placed on your tray.

options.d: Reach for the candle flame

event: You have taken your first shaky steps. You see the family dog sleeping across the room. This is your first chance to practice walking toward a specific target.

options.d: Shout to wake the dog up

event: Your parents are trying to teach you your first intentional words. They keep repeating "Mama" and "Papa," but you are distracted by a bright red ball on the floor.

options.d: Grunt and reach out

event: You are at a playground for the first time. Other toddlers are playing in a sandbox, while a tall plastic slide looms nearby.

options.a: Join the kids in the sand
options.d: Play with a stick in the grass

event: You are developing a strong sense of "mine." Another child at a playdate tries to take the red ball you were playing with earlier.

options.d: Let them have it and walk away

event: You are being potty trained. You feel the urge to go while you are deep in the middle of building a tall tower of blocks.

options.b: Keep building and have an accident
options.d: Try to hold it in while playing

event: Your parents are reading you a bedtime story. They stop to ask you what you think happens next in the tale of the brave little rabbit.

options.d: Close the book and go to sleep

event: You are at a family gathering and a relative offers you a piece of dark chocolate. You've never tasted anything so bitter before.

options.c: Ask for milk to wash it down
options.d: Offer the rest to someone else

event: It is your first day of preschool. Your parent drops you off at the door of a classroom filled with unfamiliar children and colorful stations.

options.c: Wave goodbye and walk in slowly
options.d: Find a quiet corner to observe

event: During "art time," the teacher asks everyone to draw their family. You notice you don't have the right color crayon for your house.

options.d: Cry until the teacher notices

event: You are playing in the backyard and find a trail of ants leading to a hole. You have a small plastic shovel in your hand.

options.a: Dig up the hole to see inside
options.b: Squish the ants one by one
options.c: Feed them crumbs from your snack
options.d: Run away in fear

event: Your parents are arguing loudly in the kitchen about finances. You are in the living room and can hear the tension in their voices.

options.a: Go in and try to hug them
options.d: Start crying loudly to distract them

event: At preschool, a group of older kids is playing a game of "tag." They invite you to join, but they are running very fast and the game seems intense.

options.d: Suggest a slower game

event: You find a five-dollar bill dropped on the floor of a toy store. Your parent is busy looking at a shelf nearby and hasn't seen it.

options.d: Leave it where it is

event: You are learning to ride a bicycle with training wheels. You hit a bump and fall over, scraping your knee slightly.

options.d: Blame the bike and kick it constellations

event: A new baby sibling is brought home from the hospital. Everyone is giving the baby attention, and you feel a bit forgotten.

options.a: Try to help care for the baby
options.c: Retreat to your room to play
options.d: Ask for a "big kid" treat

event: It's your first day of Kindergarten. The teacher asks for a volunteer to stand up and tell the class their name and favorite animal.

options.d: Wait to be called on voluntarily

event: You are at a friend's house and they want to play a "doctor" game that makes you feel a little uncomfortable.

options.b: Say you want to play something else
options.d: Tell their parents

event: You are learning to read. You come across a word you don't know in a book about space.

options.c: Skip the word and keep going
options.d: Close the book in frustration

event: Your school is holding a "Talent Show." You have been practicing a simple magic trick, but now you're feeling nervous about performing in front of everyone.

options.b: Back out at the last minute
options.c: Ask a friend to join you
options.d: Change to a simpler "talent" (like jumping)

event: You are now in first grade. A classmate is being teased by a group of kids for wearing "babyish" shoes.

options.d: Tell a teacher quietly

event: You are given a small allowance for the first time. You see a cool toy you want, but it costs more than you have.

options.d: Try to "borrow" the toy from a friend

event: Your teacher gives you a difficult math worksheet. You are struggling to understand the concepts.

options.d: Give up and draw on the back

event: You are invited to a sleepover at a friend's house for the first time. You're excited but also a little homesick.

options.a: Go and stay the whole night
options.b: Go but call home to be picked up
options.d: Ask if your parent can stay too

event: You are playing soccer during recess. You have a clear shot at the goal, but a teammate is in a better position.

options.b: Pass the ball to the teammate
options.d: Trip and fall on purpose

event: You find a bird with a broken wing in your backyard. It looks scared and hurt.

options.d: Keep it as a secret pet

event: Your school starts a "Gifted and Talented" program. You are invited to take the entrance exam, but it takes place during your favorite recess time.

options.d: Intentionally fail it

event: You are at a friend's house and they show you a "scary" movie that your parents wouldn't approve of.

options.c: Close your eyes during the scary parts
options.d: Go home early

event: You are now in third grade. Your teacher assigns a group project, and you are paired with the "class clown" who doesn't want to do any work.

options.b: Try to motivate them to help
options.d: Slack off as well

event: You are at a summer camp and there's a high ropes course. You are terrified of heights, but all your friends are doing it.

options.a: Face your fear and do it
options.d: Try a lower, easier course

event: You are starting to develop a hobby. You've been practicing the piano, but it's getting harder and you're losing interest.

options.d: Only practice when forced to

event: You are at a grocery store with your parent and you see someone shoplifting a small item.

options.d: Confront the person yourself

event: You are now in fourth grade. You are starting to notice that some kids are "cooler" than others. You want to fit in, but the "cool" kids are being mean to your best friend.

options.c: Try to be friends with both
options.d: Stay neutral and quiet

event: You are given a school assignment to write a story. You have a great idea, but it's a bit unconventional and you're worried what the teacher will think.

options.d: Collaborate with a friend on a story

event: You are at a family reunion and your older cousin offers you a sip of their "special" drink (alcohol).

options.d: Ask what's in it first

event: You are playing a video game and you find a "glitch" that allows you to win easily.

options.b: Report the glitch to the developer
options.c: Avoid the glitch and play fairly
options.d: Share the glitch with your friends

event: You are entering the double digits! Your parents offer to let you choose your own extracurricular activity this year.

options.d: Volunteering at a local shelter

event: You are at school and you see a student being bullied in the hallway. The bully is much bigger than you.

options.c: Shout at the bully to stop
options.d: Record it on your phone (if you have one) or watch from afar

event: You are starting to feel more independent. Your parents give you a list of chores to do over the weekend, but your friends invite you to the movies.

options.b: Skip chores and go to movies
options.d: Stay home and do chores only

event: You are at a school dance and you see someone you like across the room. You want to ask them to dance, but you're nervous.

options.c: Wait for them to ask you
options.d: Leave the dance early

event: You are now in middle school. The workload has increased significantly, and you have your first major research paper due. You find a website that has a paper very similar to your topic.

options.a: Use it as a reference only
options.d: Ask a parent to write it for you

event: A group of popular students invites you to hang out at the mall after school, but they have a reputation for shoplifting small items for fun.

options.c: Make an excuse and stay home
options.d: Tell them it's a bad idea

event: You are starting to go through puberty and your body is changing. You feel self-conscious about your appearance.

options.d: Compare yourself to others online

event: You are at a family dinner and your grandfather starts making comments that you find offensive or outdated.

options.d: Agree with him to avoid conflict

event: You are now 12. You are given your first smartphone. You have to decide how to use it.

options.d: Keep it for emergencies only

event: You are at school and you find a wallet with a significant amount of cash inside. There is no ID.

options.b: Turn it in to the office
options.c: Try to find the owner yourself
options.d: Donate the cash to charity

event: You are starting to think about your future career. Your parents want you to be a doctor, but you are more interested in technology.

options.c: Try to find a middle ground
options.d: Don't think about it yet

event: You are at a party and someone offers you a cigarette. You've heard about the health risks, but you want to fit in.

options.d: Tell them it's gross

event: You are officially a teenager! You are starting to feel more attracted to people and you have your first real crush.

options.a: Ask them out on a date
options.d: Keep your feelings to yourself

event: Your school offers an advanced "Cyber Security" elective, but it's at the same time as the popular "Introduction to Film" class that all your friends are taking.

options.d: Ask your parents to choose

event: You are at a friend's house and they show you how to bypass the parental controls on their computer to access restricted sites.

options.d: Report it to their parents

event: You are starting to feel more pressure from school and extracurriculars. You are feeling overwhelmed and stressed.

options.d: Just keep pushing through

event: You are now in high school. You are starting to think about your college applications and your future. You have the opportunity to join a prestigious academic club.

options.d: Get a part-time job

event: You've become quite proficient at coding. You discover a vulnerability in your school's grading software that would allow you to change your own marks.

options.a: Fix it and tell the school
options.d: Ignore it completely

event: A girl you've had a crush on for a while finally starts talking to you more. She asks if you want to study together at the library this weekend.

options.d: Decline, saying you're busy

event: Your parents are going through a difficult time and are considering a divorce. They ask for your input on how you feel about it.

options.b: Tell them to do what's best
options.d: Try to help them reconcile

event: You are now 15. You have the opportunity to take a summer internship at a local tech startup, but it means giving up your traditional summer vacation with your friends.

options.d: Decline and just relax

event: At your internship, you notice a senior developer taking credit for work that you actually did.

options.c: Let it go to stay humble
options.d: Subtly mention it in a meeting

event: You are starting to think about your first car. Your parents offer to help you buy one, but you have to contribute half the cost.

options.a: Get a job to save up
options.c: Ask for a loan from them
options.d: Decide you don't need a car yet

event: You are at a party and someone offers you a pill that they say will help you focus and study better for your upcoming exams.

options.d: Tell a trusted adult later

event: You are now 16. You are starting to think about your college applications and your future. You have the opportunity to apply for a prestigious scholarship.

options.d: Get a part-time job

event: You are finally dating the girl you liked. She wants to go to a big, unsupervised party on Friday night, but you have a major coding competition early Saturday morning.

options.a: Go to the party with her
options.b: Stay home and rest for the competition
options.c: Go to the party for an hour then leave
options.d: Invite her to watch you compete instead

event: You are starting to feel more pressure from your parents to choose a "stable" career path like law or medicine, despite your success in tech.

options.b: Stick to your passion for tech
options.d: Ignore the pressure and decide later

event: You discover an online community of "white hat" hackers who find and report security flaws for rewards. They invite you to join a high-stakes "bug bounty" hunt.

options.d: Try it secretly without telling anyone

event: You are now 17. You are starting to receive college acceptance letters. You've been accepted to a top-tier tech university far from home and a solid local university with a full scholarship.

options.c: Take a gap year to travel
options.d: Defer your enrollment for a year

event: Your girlfriend is going to a different college in another state. You have to decide the future of your relationship.

options.d: Decide to wait and see how it goes

event: You are graduating from high school! You have the opportunity to give a speech at the graduation ceremony as the valedictorian or a top student.

options.c: Ask a friend to give it with you
options.d: Write the speech but have someone else read it

event: You are preparing to move away for college. You have to decide what to do with all your childhood belongings and your old computer setup.

options.b: Sell most of it for extra cash
options.c: Donate it to a local charity
options.d: Leave it all at your parents' house

event: You are now 18 and at university. Your first week is filled with "orientation" parties. You are feeling a bit overwhelmed by the social scene.

options.c: Find a small group of like-minded people
options.d: Stay in your dorm and play games

event: Your first semester midterms are approaching. A group of students in your "Advanced Algorithms" class has a copy of last year's exam, which is rumored to be identical to this year's.

options.b: Report the leak to the professor
options.c: Ignore it and study the textbook
options.d: Form a legitimate study group instead

event: You are struggling to balance your long-distance relationship with your heavy course load. Your girlfriend feels neglected and wants you to visit her during a weekend when you have a major project due.

options.a: Visit her and risk the project
options.c: Ask her to visit you instead
options.d: Suggest a temporary break-up

event: A professor notices your exceptional coding skills and offers you a position as a Research Assistant. It pays well but will take up 15 hours of your week.

options.d: Ask to start next semester

event: You are now 19. Your long-distance relationship has finally reached a breaking point. Your girlfriend tells you she has met someone else at her college.

options.d: Focus entirely on your work to forget

event: You are working on a research project when you discover a major flaw in a widely used open-source security protocol. Reporting it could make you famous in the tech world, but it might also alert malicious actors before a patch is ready.

options.d: Keep it to yourself for now

event: You are offered a high-paying summer internship at a major defense contractor. Some of your peers criticize the company for its involvement in controversial military tech.

options.a: Take the internship for the money/experience
options.c: Research the company more before deciding
options.d: Apply to a different, less controversial firm instead

event: You've been spending a lot of time in the lab. Your health is starting to suffer from lack of sleep and a poor diet.

options.a: Join a gym and change diet
options.c: Ignore it until the semester ends
options.d: Take supplements to keep going

event: You are now 20. A group of friends from your Research Assistant days approaches you with a startup idea: a revolutionary encrypted messaging app. They want you to be the Lead Developer.

options.b: Decline to focus on finishing your degree
options.c: Offer to help as a part-time consultant
options.d: Steal the idea and start your own company

event: The startup is gaining traction, but it's consuming all your time. Your grades are starting to slip for the first time in your life. Your advisor warns you that you might lose your honors status.

options.a: Drop out to go full-time on the startup
options.b: Scale back startup work to save your grades
options.c: Hire someone to help with your schoolwork
options.d: Push through with minimal sleep to do both

event: A venture capital firm offers your startup a massive investment, but they want a 40% stake and a seat on the board, which would give them significant control.

options.b: Reject it and look for other investors
options.d: Bootstrap the company yourself instead

event: You are nearing graduation. The startup is stable but not yet profitable. You receive a lucrative job offer from a "Big Tech" company that would pay off all your student loans instantly.

options.c: Try to do both (Big Tech job + startup on side)
options.d: Sell the startup and take the job

event: Graduation day has arrived. You are standing in your cap and gown, but your phone is buzzingâ€”a major security breach has been detected in your startup's app. You are supposed to walk across the stage in ten minutes.

options.a: Skip the walk and fix the breach
options.b: Walk the stage, then fix it
options.d: Shut down the servers immediately

event: Your quick action saved the app, and the story of you skipping your graduation to protect user data goes viral. This brings in a wave of new users and potential investors.

options.a: Capitalize on the PR and raise funds
options.b: Stay humble and focus on the product
options.c: Hire a PR firm to manage the image
options.d: Use the fame to launch a second product

event: You meet someone new at a tech conference. They are brilliant, share your interests, and there's an immediate spark. However, they work for a direct competitor.

options.c: Try to recruit them to your startup
options.d: Avoid them to prevent conflict of interest

event: Your startup is finally profitable. You have a significant amount of personal income for the first time. Your parents are struggling with their mortgage and ask for help.

options.c: Offer them a job at your company
options.d: Decline to keep your finances separate

event: You are now 22. A major tech giant offers to acquire your startup for a life-changing sum of money. You would have to work for them for three years as part of the deal.

options.b: Reject the offer and stay independent
options.d: Propose a partnership instead of a sale

event: One of your original co-founders wants to leave the company to pursue a different path. They own a significant portion of the shares.

options.b: Let them keep the shares as a silent partner
options.c: Help them sell the shares to an outside investor
options.d: Try to convince them to stay

event: You are invited to give a TED talk about your journey and the importance of data privacy. You are still somewhat introverted and nervous about public speaking.

options.d: Do it but keep the talk very short

event: After your talk, you are approached by a government agency. They want you to build a "backdoor" into your encrypted app for national security purposes.

options.d: Publicly expose their request

event: You are now 23. The government starts putting pressure on your company through regulatory hurdles because of your refusal. Your board of directors is getting nervous.

options.d: Step down as CEO to protect the company

event: You have relocated to a tech-friendly European city. The move was expensive and disruptive, but your user base is growing rapidly in the region. You feel lonely in a new country.

options.c: Use dating apps to meet people
options.d: Fly friends and family out to visit often

event: You meet a local artist at a gallery opening. She is fascinated by your world, and you are drawn to her creativity. She doesn't care about your status or wealth.

options.c: Commission her to do art for your office
options.d: Introduce her to your tech friends

event: A major bug is discovered in your app that accidentally leaked some user metadata. It wasn't a full breach, but it violates your core promise of privacy.

options.b: Fix it quietly and hope no one notices
options.c: Downplay the severity in a PR statement
options.d: Offer a bounty to whoever found it to stay quiet

event: You are now 24. Your transparency actually increased user trust in the long run. You are now considered a leader in the "Ethical Tech" movement. You are invited to advise a global commission on internet freedom.

options.b: Decline to focus on your company
options.d: Write a white paper instead of attending meetings

event: Your company is now a "Unicorn" (valued at over $1 billion). You are incredibly wealthy on paper, but you still live a relatively modest life. Your friends from college are starting to treat you differently.

options.a: Throw a lavish party for them
options.d: Invest in your friends' projects/startups

event: You are feeling burnt out after years of intense work. Your co-founders suggest you take a three-month sabbatical.

options.d: Work remotely from a tropical location

event: During your break, you realize you've missed having a deep personal connection. You think back to the artist you met earlier.

options.d: Decide you're better off alone for now

event: You are now 25. Your relationship with the artist is flourishing. She challenges you to think about the world beyond code. She wants you to go on a month-long backpacking trip through Asia with her.

options.c: Suggest a shorter, more luxurious trip
options.d: Invite her to join you on a business trip instead

event: While traveling, you see firsthand how technology is used in developing nations. You have an idea for a non-profit branch of your company to provide secure communication for activists.

options.b: Just donate money to existing charities
options.c: Incorporate the features into your main app
options.d: Forget the idea and enjoy the trip

event: You return to work refreshed. Your company is facing a new challenge: a massive "Big Tech" competitor has launched a nearly identical app for free, subsidized by their other businesses.

options.d: Pivot your company to a new niche

event: Your girlfriend's art career is taking off, and she's offered a prestigious residency in a different city. She asks if you'd consider moving again or doing long-distance.

options.a: Move with her and work remotely
options.d: Break up to focus on your respective careers

event: You are now 26. You are starting to think about your legacy. You have the opportunity to write a book about your experiences and your philosophy on technology.

options.d: Keep your thoughts private for now

event: You are approached by a major university to teach a semester-long course on "Ethics in Technology." It would require a significant time commitment.

options.c: Offer to give a few guest lectures instead
options.d: Create an online course instead

event: Your long-distance relationship is struggling. The lack of physical presence is taking a toll on both of you.

options.c: Have a serious talk about the future
options.d: End the relationship amicably

event: After your talk, you both decide to make a real effort to be together. She decides to move back to your city after her residency ends. You are considering buying a house together.

options.d: Buy a house in your name only

event: You are now 27. Your company is going public (IPO). This will make you and your co-founders incredibly wealthy, but it also means you'll be answerable to shareholders.

options.b: Stay private and find other funding
options.c: Delay the IPO for a few years
options.d: Sell the company before the IPO

event: By staying private, you have more freedom but less liquid cash. You want to expand into hardwareâ€”creating a "secure phone." This is a high-risk, high-reward move.

options.c: Partner with an existing hardware company
options.d: Crowdfund the project to gauge interest

event: The crowdfunding campaign is a massive success, proving there's a huge demand for privacy-focused hardware. However, production delays are starting to frustrate your backers.

options.b: Push the factory to work faster (risking quality)
options.c: Offer refunds to anyone who wants them
options.d: Hire a more experienced supply chain manager

event: You finally ship the first batch of secure phones. They receive rave reviews for their security features, but some users find the interface too complex.

options.a: Simplify the interface in an update
options.d: Launch a "Lite" version of the phone

event: You are now 28. You and your partner are very happy living together. She suggests it might be time to start a family.

options.a: Agree and start trying for a baby
options.c: Suggest waiting a few more years
options.d: Discuss adoption or other options instead

event: A former employee sues your company, claiming they were the true "brain" behind your most successful feature and demanding a huge settlement.

options.d: Offer them a consultant role to drop the suit

event: The court case is long and draining, but you eventually win. However, the stress has taken a toll on your mental health.

options.d: Start a new, relaxing hobby

event: Your "workaholism" is starting to affect your relationship. Your partner feels like she's living with a ghost.

options.a: Commit to a strict "no work after 6 PM" rule
options.b: Take her on a surprise romantic getaway
options.c: Explain that this is just a busy phase
options.d: Suggest couples therapy

event: You are now 29. Your "no work after 6 PM" rule is working well. You feel more connected to your partner and more refreshed at work. You are invited to be the keynote speaker at the world's largest tech conference.

options.b: Decline to stay focused on your life
options.c: Suggest a joint keynote with your co-founder
options.d: Do a virtual keynote instead

event: You are approached by a major political party to run for office, given your reputation for ethics and tech expertise.

options.c: Offer to be a policy advisor instead
options.d: Support a different candidate instead

event: Your partner surprises you with the news that she's pregnant. Even though you wanted to wait a few more years, it's happening now.

options.b: Express your concerns but be supportive
options.c: Ask for some time to process it
options.d: Suggest you weren't ready yet

event: You are preparing for the baby's arrival. You need to decide how much time you'll take off from your company once the baby is born.

options.a: Take a full paternity leave (3+ months)
options.d: Don't take any formal leave, just play it by ear

event: You are now 30 and a father! Your daughter is born healthy. The first few months are a blur of sleepless nights and diapers. You are finding it hard to stay focused at work.

options.a: Hire a nanny to help at home
options.d: Delegate more of your CEO duties to your co-founders

event: With more time at home, you notice your daughter is fascinated by the glowing screens of your devices. You need to decide on your "tech-parenting" philosophy.

options.d: Focus on physical toys instead

event: Your company is thriving under your co-founders' leadership. You start to wonder if you should step down as CEO permanently and take a different role, like Chief Technology Officer (CTO).

options.d: Leave the company entirely to start something new

event: As Chairman, you have more free time. You decide to use your wealth to start a philanthropic foundation. What should be its primary focus?

options.d: Funding medical research for rare diseases

event: You are now 31. Your foundation is making a real difference in supporting investigative journalism. However, some powerful interests are unhappy with the stories being uncovered and are targeting you personally.

options.c: Hire personal security for your family
options.d: Publicly defend the journalists and your foundation

event: Your public defense of journalism makes you a hero to many, but the threats continue. Your partner is worried about your daughter's safety.

options.a: Move your family to a more secure location
options.c: Step back from the foundation's public face
options.d: Ignore the threats and keep going as usual

event: You've stepped back from the spotlight. You're spending more time with your daughter, who is now a toddler. She's showing a lot of interest in your old computer parts.

options.d: Keep the tech away from her for nowmountains

event: A former rival from your early startup days reaches out. Heâ€™s fallen on hard times and asks for a job at your company or a loan to start over.

options.d: Mentor him on his next idea

event: You are now 32. Your daughter is growing up fast. You and your partner are considering having another child.

options.c: Let's wait a few more years
options.d: Let's discuss it more later

event: You are approached by a major film studio that wants to make a movie about your life and the founding of your company.

options.a: Sell the rights and be involved
options.b: Sell the rights but stay out of it
options.d: Write the screenplay yourself instead

event: Your second child, a son, is born. Life is more chaotic than ever, but you feel a deep sense of fulfillment. Your company is now a global household name.

options.c: Start a new, smaller project on the side
options.d: Focus entirely on your family for a year

event: During your leave, you have a lot of time to reflect. You realize you've achieved almost everything you set out to do. You start to think about what's next.

options.b: Start a new venture in a different field
options.d: Just enjoy your life with your family

event: You are now 33. Your new venture is in the field of renewable energy. You want to use your tech expertise to solve the climate crisis.

options.d: Focus on carbon capture technology

event: Your fusion project is incredibly ambitious and expensive. You need to raise a massive amount of capital.

options.d: Launch a massive crowdfunding campaign again

event: The crowdfunding campaign is the largest in history, showing the world's desire for clean energy. However, the technical challenges of fusion are even greater than you anticipated.

options.b: Pivot to a simpler energy solution
options.d: Keep pushing with your current team

event: Your partnership with the university is yielding promising results. You've made a breakthrough in plasma containment. The world is watching.

options.b: Keep it secret until it's fully proven
options.d: Share the findings with the global scientific community for free

event: You are now 34. Your decision to share the fusion breakthrough for free has accelerated the global transition to clean energy. You are being hailed as one of the most influential people in history.

options.b: Decline the fame and stay private
options.c: Use your influence to advocate for other causes
options.d: Focus on your family and your next project
